greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Keep just the digits of n that appear exactly once; write 0 if all digits disappear.
comment: Digits that appear more than once in n are erased. Leading zeros are erased unless the result is 0. If all digits are erased, we write 0 for the result (A320485 is another version, which uses -1 for the empty string).
More than the usual number of terms are shown in order to reach some interesting examples.
The number of d-digit numbers n for which a(n) > 0 is at most d*9^d, so in this sense most a(n) are 0. - _Robert Israel_, Oct 24 2018

The set of numbers with the property that their digits appear at least twice is of asymptotic density 1 (and the set of numbers that have a digit that occurs only once is of density 0), so in that sense it is rather exceptional for large n to have a(n) > 0. - _M. F. Hasler_, Oct 24 2018
reference: Eric Angelini, Posting to Sequence Fans Mailing List, Oct 24 2018
link: Robert Israel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000

N. J. A. Sloane, Coordination Sequences, Planing Numbers, and Other Recent Sequences (II), Experimental Mathematics Seminar, Rutgers University, Jan 31 2019, Part I, Part 2, Slides. (Mentions this sequence)
example: 1231 becomes 23, 1123 becomes 23, 11231 becomes 23, and 11023 becomes 23 (as we don't accept leading zeros). Note that 112323 disappears immediately and we get 0.
maple: if S = {} then return n fi;
program: (PARI) a(n) = {my(d=digits(n), v = vector(10), res = 0); for(i=1,#d, v[d[i]+1]++); for(i=1,#d,if(v[d[i]+1]==1, res=10*res+d[i]));res}
return int('0'+''.join(d if str(n).count(d) == 1 else '' for d in str(n))) # _Chai Wah Wu_, Nov 19 2018
xref: See A320485 for a different version.
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Oct 24 2018
